title: 114_hr5052
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Opioid Program Evaluation Act" or the "OPEN Act." It involves the evaluation of the Department of Justice program's performance. The Opioid Program Evaluation Act, also known as the OPEN Act, mandates the evaluation of the Comprehensive Opioid Abuse Grant Program administered by the Department of Justice. The Attorney General is required to conduct an interim evaluation of opioid abuse and distribution in the United States, as well as identify outcomes for funded activities within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General is mandated to identify outcomes and metrics for activities funded by the Comprehensive Opioid Abuse Grant Program. Grantees must collect and report data based on these metrics, with the outcomes and metrics to be published within 30 days of completion. The National Academy of Sciences will publish the results of the interim and final evaluations of the Comprehensive Opioid Abuse Grant Program within 90 days. The Attorney General must arrange with the National Academy of Sciences for these evaluations. The Department of Health and Human Services program will be evaluated for performance. The Department of Health and Human Services programs will undergo evaluation to assess opioid abuse assistance programs and outcomes within specified timeframes. The Secretary will require grantees to collect data based on identified metrics and report to the Department of Health and Human Services. Outcomes and metrics will be published within 30 days of completion, and evaluations will be conducted by the National Academy of Sciences. The National Academy of Sciences will evaluate programs and publish results to relevant committees. The Secretary will collaborate with the National Academy of Sciences or other entities for evaluations. If a program is being evaluated under another law, the Secretary may choose not to conduct a separate evaluation. SEC. 4. DEFINITION.

The term "opioid" is defined as "opiate" in the Controlled Substances Act.

SEC. 5. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED.

No extra funds are authorized for this Act.

SEC. 6. MATTERS REGARDING CERTAIN FEDERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT ASSISTANCE.

Amendment to the Justice Assistance Act of 1984 authorizes $16,000,000 for Federal law enforcement assistance in fiscal year 2022. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
